ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I think this course is quite difficult but I would recommend it to other students.

It is a difficult course but very essential in setting up foundation for economics student. The course evolves from decision making of individual to that of the whole economy, which is related closely to macroeconomics
It is required by first-year Econ PhD students. Highly recommended for those who want to study or research in related areas.
It establishes the fundamentals of economics.
The material is important, even for an SOM student like me. However, I think the department should realize that non-Econ students have very different backgrounds

This course is a requirement for first-year graduate students in the Economics program, and is an introduction/review of key concepts of demand, and market theories. Undergraduate students with strong mathematics and economics backgrounds should be able to handle this course as well.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course gave me a broad introduction to advanced microeconomics and, although I had already seen some material , I learnt new things as well.
The course evolves from decision making of individual to that of the whole economy. Thus it deepens my understanding of connection between microeconomics and macroeconomics.
I could learn techniques frequently used in solving problems in economics.
This was a required first-year course and I learnt a lot.
Since I came in with little knowledge, the course was challenging. However, it laid down the foundation for further coursework.
Given that I am studying accounting, it is unlikely that I will use this material in my research

It was a combination of review and learning new models. The materials in the course are fundamentals for an economist, but I would not say that it has a direct contribution to my dissertation and/or research.
It is indispensable for my research.
